text:
Tthis final episode - perhaps final episode - ?
of what we want to say about the whole

Bletchley Park story,  it's got a very
personal touch for me because this one

is triggered by that question that all
sons and daughters ask of their parents,

their Mom or their dad, and I certainly
did. I said to my Dad: "Dad what did you do

in the war?". And I got the reply - and
always did: "Codes and cyphers son. It's

absolutely top-secret". Still, I mean, this
was in the 1950-60s, I was asking.

"Can't tell you about it, sorry" My Dad was not
actually at Bletchley Park but he was

what was called a "cipher sergeant" and he
received summarized decrypts from

Bletchley Park and it was his job [at] the
place he was posted - RAF station or Naval

Station - to take the decrypts in the most
secure conditions to the person in

charge, who knew about what was called
The Ultra Secret. He had to have full

security clearance and my Dad did as
well so I'd like to tell you that story

but perhaps we ought to lead up to it a
bit more chronologically and get you

there in stages.  we left the story last
time in 1941-42.

Even the four-rotor Naval Enigma could
just about be got on top of. The Army and

Air Force one, really, from about 1940-1
was not too much trouble.

So, you've got these decrypts and they're
all wonderful and they're giving you all

of this intelligence. How on earth do you
get it out "into the field" to the

commanders that need it fast enough. If
you think about it, it would come in you

know that the the code settings are
going to be changing another 12 hours

time you'll have to work those out, you
let the the techies the "boffins" as they

called them in those days, get on with
that. But what about the intelligence

community behind them? Hut 3 and Hut 4 I
think were two of the big intelligence

Huts at Bletchley Park and their job
was to take all of the decrypts and see

what they meant and try to synthesize
them; put them all together;

decide who should get what; try to make
some sense out of it. Because, you know,

sometimes if a decrypt was saying:
"Private Schmidt is being sent to

somewhere else" the first reaction is:
"Who is Private Schmidt? What do we know about him?"

"Let's go and have a look at the card index".
So, eventually - and it had to be done very

quickly because time was of the essence
in this - intelligence digests were prepared.

The really hot stuff - the top, top, top 
secret stuff - the really

crucial things - were sent off to a man
called R. V. Jones in Whitehall, who was

indirect ... he was Churchill's intelligence
man and passed all of this stuff on to him.

In terms of the Armed Forces, and how
they got their decrypts - so they got out

to Admirals generals and so on - one of
the advantages that Bletchley Park had,

right from the start of the war, there
was an insistence that all of the

services would be at Bletchley Park. They
could have their own Hut's but

we're not having any of his nonsense,
like they had in the States, about the

Army's ... sorry(!),   the Navy's
decryption effort - it's always the Navy -

had to be totally separate to everybody
else's,  far better funded and preferably

hundreds of miles away from what the
Army was doing. It's not to say that at

Bletchley they weren't inter-service
rivalries, there were. But in the end

everybody trusted the man in the middle - 
the man who decided who got to know

about what was called the Ultra Secret. And here 
we have it, in his book. Freddy [Winterbotham]

had served in the Army in World War I.
He was 42 when World War II, started so

the young man had been in the army, been
transferred to the Air Force by World

War II. Clearly at his age you're not
going to be put up in fighter airplanes

but he became, basically, chief of the Air
Department of the Secret Intelligence

Service. And he did a superb job, because
he had to be trusted by the other services

to say who was high enough up
the chain to be entrusted with knowing
that decryption was going on in Bletchley Park.

And who had to be kept out of the
picture. Because always, as you can

imagine, the idea was to pass off the
intelligence gained as somehow having been

acquired from another source and not, of
course, from decryption. So, Freddie walked

around in a bomber jacket and I'm
assured by my Dad was a complete - how

should we say - "personality" ?! And [he] went
round and glad-handed everybody and clearly

did a superb job. And Freddie was in
charge of what were called Special

Liaison Units [SLUs]. These were people posted
out to RAF or Army or Naval stations, to act as

a liaison between the Bletchley Park mob
and the commanders who really needed

this intelligence.
So, the Bletchley Park linguists

intelligence officers and so on, prepared
agreed summaries, at the end of every day.

They were sent out over secure land-lines 
were these summaries, but there was

no way you were going to trust to that.
They were sent out encrypted over secure

land lines. As a result of encountering
the Enigma, the Allies - or rather the the

staff at Bletchley Park principally I
think - had come up with their miitary

colleagues with the idea of having a
better Enigma. A much better and more

secure machine. They came up with a Type X. 
It was an Enigma but without the flaws.

It was bigger, better, faster and above
all it would sometimes encrypt a

letter to itself so it avoided the fatal
flaw. The summaries were encrypted using

Type X and sent out over secure
land-lines. If you were taken on by Freddy,

to do this work, it didn't matter if you
were only a Leading Aircraftman Mark II -

as my dad was - if you were taken on to do the work
[then after training] you immediately got promoted to

Flight Sergeant.  [This is]  my Dad's proud 
portrait of himself, taken I think in 1943, in the

town in Yorkshire where we lived at the
time. In Harrogate, And there he is. If you

look on the right of the picture you can
see his Flight Sergeants stripes. So that

pretty well enables me to date it. He was
stationed up in the north-west of England

near a town called Carlisle, at an RAF
base called Annan. Almost you could tell

he was the right candidate for this sort
of thing because he taught himself

shorthand when he was a teenager. He
loved the idea of secret writing and he

also taught himself to type. Touch typing
nowadays with computer keyboards - some of

us ( I've have never got around to it(!).) have also
taught ourselves touch typing. So it

might be commonplace today, but in early
1943 a circular would come round saying

all those who would like to be
interested in better paid work are

invited to come and take an intelligence
test. And part of that intelligence test

would be a crossword puzzle. So my dad
had a go at it. I think it was a

[Daily] Telegraph concise crossword. You weren't
give them very long to do it. But he must

have done well enough because eventually
the call came to report to London and he

reported to part of the GC&S set
up, which wasn't in Bletchley Park, it was

still in London. [He] had loads of interviews,
loads of further tests and so on. And he was

eventually told that he'd passed the
tests and that if he accepted the job

offer he would be [after further training] 
instantly promoted to Flight Sergeant [with] more money 
and it would be a

much more interesting job. And that he
will be helping, in some small way, to win

the War. Fine. In the final stages of the
interview you got to meet Group Captain

Freddy [Winterbotham] himself. It went something
like this. And my Dad said, yes, it really

went just like that. You get called in:
"Brailsford, I have to congratulate you.

You have passed all our tests, all this you
know. What I'm now about to reveal to you

is the biggest secret of the War.If you
ever reveal a word of this - this is what

will happen to you!
[He] presses a button on his desk. In comes

the Staff Sergeant with a service
revolver fortunately not loaded but I

don't know [if] my dad knew that, at the time.
He pointed it at my dad's head and just

went 'click' . He said: "Yes we will kill you if
you ever reveal this secret!".

And, of course,  as Freddy says in the [BBC] interview
"... well we reduced them to jelly, you know"

Yes it did. My Dad was always a quiet
and rather reserved chap, And honestly I

I do believe, in some ways, it made him
slightly more introverted. It wasn't that

he wasn't a charming chap, and a great
Dad. He was. But I think, like many people

related to this work in the war, they
were worried, all the time, that not

deliberately, but just by accident,
something they said might give the game away.

He really, really, worried about it, I
can understand that now. So, anyway, we

went on -  on this basis of "What did you do
in the War, Dad ?"  "Sorry, son, I can't tell you"

for many many years afterwards. And
suddenly - all of a sudden -  I didn't even

know about Freddie Winterbotham, my Dad,
in the early 1970s, phones me up.

I was in Nottingham at the time. My Dad said:
"Look at this! You remember that I told

you how top-secret this was?". He said "The
chap who personally threatened me with

instant death if I ever revealed a word
of this - has now gone and published a book on it!

I can't believe it!" The Ultra Secret.
We weren't even supposed to say the word

"ultra" -  that's how secret it was!" 
Is that so, I thought, heavens .... !

So I said: "Come on then Dad, tell me all
about it"

Afterwards I found out that it wasn't
just Freddy being a maverick, although he was.

The reason that he got permission to
publish this - and he did get permission -

was something like the following: the
Winston Churchills and the "top brass"

in Whitehall of this world, wanted to keep
Bletchley stuff secret preferably for a

hundred years. Their American colleagues
who were building all these Bbombes near

Enigmas and replicas and were joining us [said]:
Ow! come on! You cannot keep the lid on it

for that long!" It'll become 'old hat'. No
come on, you know, you guys you've got

like a 25 or a 30 year rule?" 
And still Whitehall were saying: "Not nearly long

enough we need far longer than that"
And the Americans said: "Look, we are far better with

the stuff than you are." I don't think
they quite had a Freedom of Information

Act but they made it very clear that
they were going to tell at least some of

the story after 30 years", Around about
1974, all of a sudden, Freddie who'd

[always] wanted to publish a book and
being told resolutely "No!",  suddenly gets

the go-ahead [to publish].
I think - I'm cynical about this - that some

of the top brass had worked out that
Freddie's story about: "Yes it's top secret,

there's all these boffins doing this
wonderful stuff but I don't know the

details. But I will tell you how I
recruited my cipher sergeants"

Absolutely ideal! No technicalities involved 
and yet it

sent a clear signal, across the Atlantic,
"This is our show - we're going to get in first".

you know. So, that's why Freddie went
on a book tour and cheerfully would sign

books.  So my Dad went up after the talk,
introduced himself. It was the first time

he met Freddy since he was threatened
with instant death, I think. And as you

can see on the description here [in]
Freddy's wonderful handwriting you know

what does it say?  "F. Brailsford - one of the
Silent Men. Signed FW Winterbotham.

So this writing is so bad my Dad has
had to write the word "silent" so that we

can decrypt the signature as it were. 
As far as my Dad was concerned what then

followed was really interesting,
glamorous in some ways, but full of cold

and muddy tents. At the same time one of
his first postings as was in late 1943

[and] was to Admiral Bert Ramsey's operation
at Portsmouth. This later merged in with

a much bigger operation because those of
you of an older generation out there,

will know that it was decided in the
lead-up to D-day in 1944 that the

Supreme Commander would of course have
to be an American since they were

putting in the great majority of men
materiel and so on. Effectively my dad

was attached as a part of the huge
encampment of people right next door to

Eisenhower's headquarters and what would
happen every day is that he would, at a

certain time, connect his Type X machine
to the secure landline from Bletchley

Park. He would get, over the teleprinter
landline, the summary, suitably encrypted.

He would set up his Type X machine. He
would then go with the decrypt off to - not
Eisenhower himself but a senior intelligence officer

who Freddie had agreed was senior enough
to be in on the Ultra Secret and know

all about it. And I think what had to
happen - I'm not sure - was that the decrypt

in some way - I'm not sure of the details -  was
then transcribed to a one-time pad, as it

was called, you know a cipher mechanism
that's used once only. [It was]  taken into

Eisenhower deciphered in front of him,
you know strong security at all stages.

Eventually, once the message about this
crucial thing about, I don't know, Timing

of D-day",  or whatever, was got through, the
Intelligence Officer would come back

shake my Dad by the hand and the two of
them had to solemnly burn all of the

transcripts and stir the ashes and throw
them away. And all this. It was almost a

ritual, my Dad said, that you had to go
through to destroy the evidence.

And I said: "Well what ...  were there any
problems?" And he said: "Well, apart from not

being able to sleep in the tents and the
constant buzz of airplanes taking off,
and so on, the biggest problem were people both on

the American and the English sides who
were fairly senior, but not senior enough [for Ultra],

jumping up and down and starting to say:
"Come over here, Brailsford, anything you

show to those Americans you show to me!
And having to show them your top secret

orders that said that wasn't true and
then watching, in great glee, as a

US vs. England shouting match broke out.  
Thefurther adventures [for my Dad] involved having to

follow behind Eisenhower's headquarters
[that were] set up a little bit later in  1944;

crossing to Northern France. Of course
you needed the intelligence operation

right behind the leaders. At the same
time Churchill  was completely and totally

paranoid about not wanting the SLUs
and the Type X machinery to get too

close to Berlin because what Churchill was
worried about - and it's even mentioned in

the "Imitation Game", quite correctly.
Churchill was paranoid not so much about

the Germans but about the Russians
getting a hold of this technology.

I think my dad was demobilized at VE Day
which is mentioned in Freddie's book. I

think he was in the Ardennes in Belgium
at the time

and everything went very smoothly till
the end of the war. But that's just part

of the story and I suppose my friends
and so on say to me: "Well, this is amazing

you know, your Dad was one of these
Cipher Sergeants. Do you think it's got

anything to do with you being interested
in puzzles and Sudoku and computers?"

[Sighs!]  I have not the slightest
doubt it is. If you believe in genetics

at all, I now look back at what my dear
Dad was interested in and how he really

love to have explained to him everything
I was doing more or less insofar as he

could follow it. He's not in any way up
in the Alan Turing genius category,

not at all. But he was ... he had that talent
for taking immense pains about things

and plodding on for ever until he
understood it, and was very methodical

and all that. So, yeah, I think it was
inevitable, folks, that's probably a large

part of the reason why I turned out to
be a computer scientist.
